Okay, yeah. The BIG W result was quite soft in the EBIT level in the second half. Was that, again, a third quarter story or was that – what's the reason for that?

Well, EBIT for us improved really nicely in the second half for the BIG W result. And I've seen that that was put down to the stimulus payment in some of the commentary that's been written. What I can share with you is that BIG W has been on a path of improvement for the entire half. So – and it's a nice, steady, sustainable improvement in that business that, as Julie alluded to, we're seeing continue into this year. And part of it has got to be what you're alluding to, the softer sales. But even within that, we've seen improving performance from that business over the course of the half, not just the last quarter.

And finally just from me, just to clarify, the extra $120 million in provisions taken for Dick Smith, the lease tail provisions, are they to do with stores that are planning to be closed currently? Could you just clarify what's in the $120 million?
Tom.

It's several things. So it's obviously goodwill component, inventory component, fixed asset component and lease restructuring. So we just decided to take the whole hit this year and just make sure we can move on and not worry about it.
And the lease restructuring component, is that...
Yeah.
To do with the current 50 stores or so that are currently targeted to be closed? Is that what it (1:26:23)?
We've closed – I think we've closed, someone will correct me, about 70 odd up to...
72, yeah, yeah, now. And so we've got to – looking at possibly another tranche here for this year, subject to, obviously, a sale process that's going on.
Yeah, okay. Fine, thanks.
Yeah. Can we give it to Shaun? He's been as keen as mustard, but he won't sit in the back row.
He sits here in the front.

Punished for the back row, understandable. Just a question – Shaun Cousins, JPMorgan. Just a question regarding gaming and Victoria in particular. Given the changes to the ATM regulations that occurred on the 1 of July in Victoria, how does that impact current trading and how does that impact the anticipated uplift you thought you'd get from the broader changes to Victorian gaming that occurred last week?

Yeah. The – what happens when changes are made in not only that environment but most environments is you get an initial hit and then things start to return to somewhat more normal. And in relation to the ATMs, it's hard to pin, Shaun, that on one thing, because what's also have been happening in the Victorian environment is of course has been an adjustment in machine numbers that's been occurring over the same period. So, being able to say that much for ATM and that much for the removal of gaming machines has been difficult. It's not changed our outlook in terms of what we expect as our return from the Victorian hotels over the coming year.
So you think – you still think you could get maybe A$80 million to A$100 million EBIT uplift out of Vic gaming changes, playing the operator role?
I don't think we've come out and said what the number is, but we expect that we will get what we had previously taken aim at.

Yeah. Just a question maybe for Tjeerd. You made the point that a number of buyers had been through the Category Lab but not all. Can you confirm that all buyers and people in the supermarket business are on the same KPIs, because feedback from the trade is that that's not the case, that some appear sales-driven, some appear category growth driven, some appear margin driven? And it's a little bit of an inconsistent message that's coming from Woolworths in terms of what's important to them. And I'm curious whether or not those that have been part of the Category Lab, whether that's a factor in that?
Tjeerd, you want have a crack at that one?

Yeah. I think you asked me the same question when we were in Eastgardens before, and I'll give the same answer. It's market share growth, it's top line growth and making sure we have right choice for customers. So – and every category is different, so that's why every tactic is different, because sometimes we lead in market share, sometimes we underperform, sometimes we have better sales. So I think the inconsistency is because not every category is in the same shape, so.

Okay. And just a question, Tom, I think you indicated that Dick Smith sale was several weeks away a month or so ago. Can you just talk a bit about anticipated timing? Obviously, you've had a management change and is the possibility that Woolworths has to just shut all of these stores and – if they can't find a buyer?

I believe we're just in a process; these things can take longer, Shaun. It's just a matter of working through it and seeing if we can get an outcome. So I wouldn't read too much into it. It's just taking longer.
Yeah, sorry, just finally one more. We're assuming that 3% to 6% NPAT growth guidance assumes that the EGM is not successful, the EGM on a dollar base.

The EGM, just to be clear on what that resolution is, is for 2016 and onwards. There's no – if the worse was to happen, 2016 is when it would kick in. So there's nothing from that point of view. So any – sorry, Dave.

Grant, Dave Cooke from Nomura. Just staying on Dick Smith for a couple of seconds, you talked previously about closing 100 stores. With the increase in the provision, are you looking to increase that number of stores that you close? I know that you probably reticent to tell us an exact number at the moment, but is it likely to look a bit north of 100 stores?

We've gotten – we've completed what we set out to do and our ambitions in terms of the number of stores we're going to close is unchanged. And that's been our approach to this since the announcement of the consolidation and divestment. We've known the stores we're going to close, that's not changed. We've not gone back in and revised it up or down. We're in the process of doing what we set out to do and it's 72, I think, so far.

The profit that you've made in the full year includes losses on a number of those stores, which is now being closed. Can you give us an indication as to what your run rate of the stores you have remaining open is, what your EBIT run rate is?
I don't have that off the top of my head. Tom, do you?
Are you able to get back to us on it?
I don't think so.
Your lease provision.
It's a good question.
Your lease provisions sitting off balance sheet, can you give us an indication as to what they are for the Dick Smith stores that are remaining open?
Sorry, Dave, I don't.
The lease obligation that you've got off balance sheet for the Dick Smith stores that are remaining open, are you able to give us an indication as to how much that is?
No. No, look, we're in the middle of a sales process and I think that's quite a detailed question and we normally don't make that information available, so.
But you would have made it available to anyone who's looking at the IM.
Yeah, well, if you sign a confidentiality agreement, I'd be happy to give it to you, mate.
I'll sign it afterwards. Can you give us an indication, please, as to what you're expecting your interest rates to be, effective interest rate to be in FY 2013?
I missed it again, sorry.
The effective interest rate for FY 2013.
The interest rate for FY 2013?
Effective?
For us, the weighted average rate? It's just over 7%, 7.23%, yeah.
Thank you. And can you give us an indication, please, you're talking about 10,000 customers looking at Masters online. What's your conversion rate sitting at at the moment?
Penny, have you got a number?
I could actually...
Sorry, Melinda.

(1:32:42) I was talking to Christine Cross about the (1:32:45) that has a lot to do with other general merchandise online sites and our conversion rate is actually right on track with what she'd consider...

Thank you. What she'd consider as industry best practice. So whilst I'm not going to declare what the actual number is, initially when I first saw it, being a bricks and mortar person, I thought, oh, no, this is – we get 10,000 people, we should be getting – half of these people should buy something surely. But, of course, when you have a look at industry best practice, we're actually sitting above where that is already only after two months of being online.
We've still got quite a bit to put online, David, is the other thing I'd say. It's really limited range at the moment, but it's increasing on a week-by-week basis.
Did Cellarmasters add or subtract from the EBIT margin coming through in food and liquor?
Cellarmasters add or subtract?
Yeah.
It's additive, it's a very small business.
Added to actual margin.
Yeah, it's very small.
So we'll go online now and just take any questions that are online if we can.
Yes, thank you. We have a question from Tom Kierath with Morgan Stanley. Please go ahead.

Good morning, Grant, Tjeerd. Just a question on the impact of floods in the PPP, did you manage to claim back all the cost associated with that? I just wanted to understand how soft the base was for the second half 2012?
Yeah, I don't think we were ever able to claim back everything from the floods
I expect there's still a few being discussed, but, yeah, we got the majority of what damages we were entitled to.
I think Coles said it was something like $30 million, it's in that range?

We said that there was a – in last year's numbers, we said there was a A$38 million impact in the result which included a whole range of things. If we had recoverable costs, we would have provided for the insurance recovery expectation.
The A$38 million included New Zealand.
Yeah, which would have been in the A$38 million number.

Okay. Thanks. And also just on the working capital and inventory more specifically, this picked up and I understand there's a Masters impact there, is there also a private label impact? Do you have to carry more inventory as a result of increasing the penetration there?
There is.

It's not so much private label. The areas that we point out in relation to inventory is certainly the Masters, the increasing number of supermarkets, Dan Murphy's and the like that we've had this year. But the other element is the global sourcing and the level of global sourcing. We indicated that that more or less doubled and so we're carrying more stock as a result of that, incremental indent stock as we call it, and that's a pretty big increase. And we would expect that to increase again as we continue to grow our globally-sourced products.
Thank you. The next question comes from Daniel Broeren with RBS. Please go ahead.

Good afternoon. I've just got a question on the property investments, please. Just firstly, what's planned around the exit of property assets, I guess, more specifically what's the amount that's ready for sale and what's the timing for that being offered to investors?

In terms of the offered to investors, look we're doing that all the time. I've got a small team that are looking at people that are interested in that portfolio, so that's really just an ongoing process. In terms of what would be available, there's probably somewhere between A$800 million or A$900 million plus depending on what you say available because it depends what condition it's in and level of – in terms of construction and level of specialty leasing, et cetera. So, yeah, it's a reasonable amount that we could put out in the market, but it's not a sell side. It's really the number of buyers that are interested in our portfolio and as you've seen, the level of demand is a bit lower this year than it was last year, but it does move around, and at the moment we are seeing some interest but it's a tough environment.
Okay. And is it fair to assume that pricing at the moment is a little softer than what it has been?

No, no. We're not giving this stuff away. I can tell you that. That's probably why we're not selling as much. We want to get a good yield. We're still pretty tough. We're just – we sold some hotels the other day at pretty good yields. So last year, we sold a Dan Murphy's up in Coffs for 6% to 7% yield. So, we don't give a really good quality assets away. So, we can bide our time.
Thank you. The next question comes from David Thomas with CLSA. Please go ahead.

Good afternoon, guys. First question centered around some inventory levels at Masters. If I sort of backstop the commentaries you've made overall about inventory, it looks like there's about A$170-odd-million or about A$11 million per store given the sort of sales guidance of north of A$20 million which is just an inventory turnover about two times. I was wondering if that's a number that you're comfortable with or something that you think is going to improve as you go forward?

First of all, your number's not right and, logically, the number only improves as the stores mature as well. So we haven't disclosed the number in relation to the stock levels sold within those stores.
You've said that the inventory number is 8.4% growth would have been, ex-ing Masters out. It would have been 3.3%. The numbers are pretty easy to work out, they're around about A$170 million.
Yeah, but the...

Yeah, we've got stores that are open. We have stores that are opening and we have a brand new – we have two DCs that we're stocking for the future opening of the stores. So the simple math doesn't quite work.
Yeah, I guess, on a store basis, perhaps it doesn't.
Yeah.

Okay. Secondly in terms of depreciation, over the last five years, the depreciation of plant and equipment has gone from sort of 22% down to 17% or if you look at it another way, you've extend the life of your plant and equivalent from 4.5 years to 6. I was wondering if there's any different mix in the business that you would point towards why that is the case or if there's some different assumptions going on there?

No, there's no great change in the – well, there is no change in the useful life of the assets or anything or the depreciation rates. It's really would just be a function of sales going up and depreciation not going up as much. If you're doing a percentage of sale which I think is what I heard you say.
Thank you. The next question comes from Phillip Kimber with Goldman Sachs. Please go ahead.

Hi, just wanted to ask a question on Australian food and liquor. The margins were pretty low in the second half and I know that's in the outcome and not how you drive the business. But over the next few years, do you think there is a point where you're going to have to reinvest more upfront for the benefit to come and we could actually have a period where margins go down in the Australian food and liquor business?

Philosophy has always been about growing dollar profit and that's not changed. We don't have a margin ambition as such and the plans that we've had this year, the plans that we've got for next year and future years are going to be about the settings we need to deliver increase EBIT for each business unit and for the group overall.

So, it's a combination of a lot of things and we've talked about a lot them here today about where we can improve our GP margin through improved global sourcing, through improved management of shrinkage. We can improve our cost line through improved store operating costs and we can improve our sales by improving the productivity in our stores as the store network and the space increase that we've put into the market starts to mature.

Can I ask a clarifying question, on the extra week in 2013, is there anything in that week that would mean that profit contribution would be unusual or should we just mathematically assume roughly a 2% benefit?
There's nothing unusual, I'll give you that part of the answer.
Thank you. Our next question comes from Andrew McLennan with CBA. Please go ahead.
Good afternoon. A quick question around the corporate and other, what's the change in rental income within that division?
Look, we don't break all that out. That includes the Masters cost, but we don't break out the rental component and so forth. But as we – as you know, we charge rent up to the Supermarket division.
Okay. In terms of the General Merchandise division, you've given floor space with Dick Smith again, can you split out the floor space for BIG W?
In the sales per square meter? I'm sorry. Maybe you can send me an email on that one. I can pick that up for you.
Are we still online? No, we're not.
There's no more questions.
There's no more questions. Okay. Any more questions in the room, any follow-up questions in the room? All right.

Thank you again for your time. Thanks again for those that have traveled out. Looking forward to catching up with you at the next half and looking forward to continuing the journey that we started 10 months ago. Thanks very much for coming.
